title: Reality TV producer reveals exactly what YOU need to do to get on Big Brother 2020
text:
One of the most successful reality TV producers in Australia has revealed her top tips for getting cast on the upcoming Big Brother reboot.

Yana Groves, who has worked on My Kitchen Rules and Bachelor In Paradise, said that authenticity and star quality is the key to winning over producers.

'What we're always looking for is people who stand out, who have the X-factor, people who have that sort of star quality,' she told Mamamia.

'Be yourself!' One of the most successful reality TV producers in Australia has revealed her top tips for getting cast on the upcoming Big Brother reboot

'But also people who are interesting... and somebody that can really entertain the crowd or the audience.'

She continued: 'My advice is always be you, be yourself. Producers are gonna know straight away if you're putting on an act.

'All we're looking for is people who are genuine and who really have the right motivation for whatever show they're going for.'

'What we're always looking for is people who stand out': Reality TV producer Yana Groves said they're after people with 'star quality' and 'x factor'. (Pictured: Skye Wheatley)

When it comes to casting dramatic people for conflict, Yana explained that they prefer to find people who have different opinions on issues.

'It's not really about creating friction,' she said. 'It's more about finding a balance of characters.'

'Those balance of characters can be any end of the spectrum, meaning, they may have opposing views... in real life, not everyone has the same opinion.'

'It's more about finding a balance of characters': When it comes to casting dramatic people for conflict, Yana explained that they prefer to find people who have different opinions on issues

She added: 'Of course, who doesn't love a good row on telly!'

Yana also said that having a strong social media following can be appealing to producers because it shows that you already 'have a presence' as a personality.

She also warned that anybody who 'tries to put on an act' during the casting process 'will be found out pretty quickly' by producers.

Former Big Brother star-turned-radio host Ryan 'Fitzy' Fitzgerald recently expressed his fear that the reality TV reboot will feature too much 'forced drama'.

'With reality television at the moment it's all about controversy,' he said.

'I feel like there's a lot of story themes being introduced into these shows, forced to cause more drama and I don't want that.'
